newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Mexico doesn't want landmines ban negotiated in UN.
newsitem.headline: Mexico doesn't want landmines ban negotiated in UN.

text.p: Mexico made clear on Thursday that for the sake of expediency, it preferred a global ban on landmines to be negotiated in the context of Canada's so-called "Ottawa process" rather than in the Conference on Disarmament.
The Ottawa process, an initiative which aims to reach a global ban on landmines by the end of 1997, was launched last October.
Western diplomats said that Mexico, a leading member of the non-aligned movement, stands alone in opposing the tackling of a landmines ban in the Geneva talks backed by the United Nations.
"They are an obstacle," one Western diplomat told Reuters.
Antonio de Icaza, Mexico's ambassador, said in a speech that the Conference should concentrate on nuclear disarmament and said the landmines crisis required "urgent solutions".
"Swiftness is not this Conference's main virtue," he said.
"We hope to conclude this year in the Ottawa process an international legally binding agreement to ban anti-personnel landmines...," he added.

China is still considering its position, but has said it is not "dead-set" against holding negotiations in the Geneva forum, while Russia -- another top mine producer and exporter -- has come on board, according to Western diplomats.
The United States has leaned on its southern neighbour to come around to negotiating a ban in the Conference on Disarmament, but has failed so far, they added.
"The Americans have lobbied in Mexico City to try to get Mexico to take a more flexible line," one said. "We were all hoping they would be more flexible, but apparently in vain."
"They are the only ones to come out firmly against this."
Many experts argue that for a ban to be universal, it should be negotiated in the Conference, whose members include China and Russia, two top mines producers and exporters.
Neither state is fully taking part in Canada's 50-country initiative, although Russia attended a January session held in Vienna as an observer.
Canada has called for the two processes to be complementary.

Pavel Grecu, Romania's envoy who currently chairs the forum, told delegates privately on Thursday that only one country opposed work on mines, a subject he called "closest to reaching consensus," according to delegates.
"It was clear he meant Mexico," one delegate said.

The Geneva forum last month adopted its 1997 agenda, which could encompass negotiations for a global ban on the use, stockpiling, production and transfer of landmines, which are blamed for the deaths of 25,000 people a year -- but consensus is required.
